presentation.title: Open space proximity
presentation.runninghead: Values resulting from open space proximity
presentation.description: Aesthetic values are typically defined as the value derived from views or proximity to open space. These values often accrue to housing or property values and are often measured using hedonic pricing. Homeowners typically gain some combination of benefits through sensory enjoyment of views of nearby open space, proximity to open space for recreation, or privacy. This storyline maps ecosytem service provision, use, and flows for open space proximity, including the type and quality of open space, location and type of housing, the presence of highways that can block easy access to open space, and flow models to connect beneficiaries to open space via walking simulation.

page.name: Open space proximity assessment
page.title: Introduction
page.description: This storyline considers the contribution of ecosystems toward providing high-quality open space, and the impact of open space on property values. The source model quantifies open space quality, the sink model maps highways that reduce privacy and obstruct direct access to open space, and the use model maps the location of homeowners. By combining these maps with a walking simulation model, actual open space proximity its potential impact on property values can be analyzed.
page.see-also: Aesthetic viewshed and proximity model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Lakefront
page.title: Lakefront
page.description:
Lakefront land is a relatively high-value open space type for nearby residents.

Role in models

Lakefront presence is used as an input to a probabilistic model to estimate open space quality.

Representation

Data show the presence or absence of lakefront land.

Source

Derived from 2001 National Land Cover Dataset.
page.see-also: Aesthetic viewshed and proximity model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: National Land Cover Dataset.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

Riverfront land is a relatively high-value open space type for nearby residents.

Role in models

Riverfront presence is used as an input to a probabilistic model to estimate open space quality.

Representation

Source

Derived from Washington State DNR hydrography data.

page.name: Woody wetland
page.title: Woody wetland
page.description:

page.name: Riparian or wetland presence and quality
page.title: Riparian or wetland presence and quality
page.runninghead: Riparian or wetland presence and quality
page.description:
Presence of riparian or wetland habitat is a relatively high-value open space type for nearby residences.

Role in models

Riparian and wetland presence data are combined with data on riparian quality (where available) to further estimate the quality of the surface water resource. Given its rarity in the Southwest, riparian habitat has been found to contribute relatively high value to nearby property.

Representation

Data are categorical.

Source

Derived from Southwest Regional GAP Analysis (SWReGAP) land cover data and riparian condition class data (Stromberg, J.C., et al. 2006. Status of the riparian ecosystem in the Upper San Pedro River, Arizona: Application of an assessment model. Environmental Monitoring and Assessment 115: 145-173.)
page.see-also: Aesthetic viewshed and proximity model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: Southwest Regional GAP Analysis land cover data and Stromberg et al. 2006.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Park
page.title: Park
page.description:
Parks are a relatively high-value open space type for nearby residents.

Role in models

Park presence is used as an input to a probabilistic model to estimate open space quality.

Representation

Data show the presence or absence of parks.

Source

State and county level land ownership data.
page.see-also: Aesthetic viewshed and proximity model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: Various state and county level ownership data.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Crime potential
page.title: Crime potential
page.description:
In urban areas, crime may reduce the value of open space for nearby residents.

Role in models

Potential for crime is used as an input to a probabilistic model to estimate open space quality. Generally, urban open space may be of lower value in high-crime or perceived high-crime areas.

Representation

Data show the presence or absence of urban areas.

Source

Washington State Office of Financial Management urban boundary data.
page.see-also: Aesthetic viewshed and proximity model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: Washington State Office of Financial Management urban boundary data.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Fire threat
page.title: Fire threat
page.description:
Fire-prone open space can reduce nearby property values.

Role in models

Fire frequency is used as an input to a probabilistic model to estimate open space quality. Generally, high fire risk would be expected to reduce a parcel's value to nearby residents.

Representation

Data are categorical, based on fire return interval.

Source

Southwest Regional GAP Analysis (SWReGAP) land cover data and The Nature Conservancy fire return interval data.
page.see-also: Aesthetic viewshed and proximity model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data sources: TNC Southwest Forest Assessment Project, Southwest Regional GAP Analysis land cover data.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Water quality
page.title: Water quality
page.description:
The quality of surface water, if present, is a determinant of open space quality for nearby residents.

Role in models

Water quality is used as an input to a probabilistic model to estimate open space quality. Generally, low water quality would be expected to reduce a parcel's value to nearby residents.

Representation

Data are categorical.

Source

Washington State Department of Ecology 303 (d) data.
page.see-also: Aesthetic viewshed and proximity model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: Washington State Department of Ecology 303 (d) data.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Formal protection
page.title: Formal protection
page.description:
The protected or unprotected legal status of the open space parcel can influence its value to nearby residents.

Role in models

Protected status is used as an input to a probabilistic model to estimate open space quality. Generally, legally protected areas are of higher value than unprotected areas, which may be developed in the future.

Representation

Data show the presence or absence of protected land.

Source

World Database on Protected Areas.
page.see-also: Aesthetic viewshed and proximity model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: World Database on Protected Areas.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Open space area
page.title: Open space area
page.description:
The area of an open space parcel can influence its value to nearby residents.

Role in models

Open space area is used as an input to a probabilistic model to estimate open space quality. Generally, larger-area parcels are of higher value than smaller parcels.

Representation

Data are in physical units of hectares per open space parcel.

Source

Calculated for all open space parcels in the case study region.
page.see-also: Aesthetic viewshed and proximity model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Potential proximity value
page.title: Potential proximity value
page.description:
The quality of potential open space for nearby residents.

Role in models

This is the output of the proximity source model, and estimates the relative quality of different areas in providing aesthetically valuable open space, based on relevant input data for the type of open space and its relative quality.

Representation

The data are in abstract units from 0-100, representing relative suitability of different parts of the landscape to provide aesthetically valuable open space. As the output of the models is probabilistic, each point contains the probability distribution for potential open space quality. The distribution can be visualized by clicking on the map; the mean value and the coefficient of variation are reported along with the probabilities.

Source

This map has been computed at your request by a Bayesian model built and calibrated by the ARIES server for the selected area.
page.see-also: Aesthetic viewshed and proximity model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Highways
page.title: Presence of highways
page.description:
The presence of highways, which limit immediate access to open space and reduce privacy.

Role in models

Highways are used as the sink layer for open space proximity. Although highways can increase access to parks and other open space, for the purposes of property value benefits from open space proximity, highways increase noise, reduce privacy, and restrict the ability to easily walk to the nearby open space parcel. They thus act as sinks in the proximity flow model.

Representation

Data show the presence or absence of highways.

Source

Census TIGER/Line Files.
page.see-also: Aesthetic viewshed and proximity model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: Census TIGER/Line Files.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Housing
page.title: Presence of housing
page.description:
Residences at who may benefit from open space proximity.

Role in models

Housing locations, housing value, and population density data are used as inputs to a probabilistic model to estimate the potential aesthetic value, as reflected in property value, of open space proximity.

Representation

Data show the presence or absence map of housing.

Source

County assessors' offices (where available), otherwise National Land Cover Dataset (NLCD) developed land.
page.see-also: Aesthetic viewshed and proximity model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: County assessors' offices.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Property value
page.title: Property value
page.description:
Property value, which may be increased with access to nearby open space.

Role in models

Housing locations, housing value, and population density data are used as inputs to a probabilistic model to estimate the potential aesthetic value, as reflected in property value, of open space proximity.

Representation

Data are in dollars per acre of property.

Source

County assessors' offices (where available).
page.see-also: Aesthetic viewshed and proximity model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: County assessors' offices.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Urban proximity
page.title: Urban proximity
page.description:
Urban proximity, measured here based on population density, reflects both the scarcity of open space and the degree of crowding, which can increase demand for open space. In dense urban areas, open space is typically more valuable, on a per-area basis, than in rural areas where open space is abundant.

Role in models

Housing locations, housing value, and population density data are used as inputs to a probabilistic model to estimate the potential aesthetic value, as reflected in property value, of open space proximity.

Representation

Data are in physical units of persons per square kilometer.

Source

U.S. Census Bureau population estimates and TIGER block group files.
page.see-also: Aesthetic viewshed and proximity model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: Census TIGER/Line Files.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Potential homeowner proximity use
page.title: Potential homeowner proximity use
page.description:
The potential property value benefit from access to open space.

Role in models

This is the output of the proximity use model, and estimates the potential property value benefit that could be provided by high-quality open space access, based on relevant input data.

Representation

The data are in abstract units from 0-100, representing relative potential property value benefit as reflected by the presence of housing, property values, and urban proxmity. As the output of the models is probabilistic, each point contains the probability distribution for potential visual blight. The distribution can be visualized by clicking on the map; the mean value and the coefficient of variation are reported along with the probabilities.

Source

This map has been computed at your request by a Bayesian model built and calibrated by the ARIES server for the selected area.
page.see-also: Aesthetic viewshed and proximity model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Possible proximate open space
page.title: Possible proximate open space
page.description:
*Possible flow maps* show the path that the carrier of the service would take if it was not intercepted by sinks. As such it considers source and use models and shows the maximum amount of flow.
For provisioning services, this corresponds to the maximum potential benefit; for preventive services, the maximum potential damage.
This map shows the flow of proximity from natural areas toward homeowners, before accounting for highways that limit local access.
page.see-also: Aesthetic viewshed and proximity model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Accessible open space
page.title: Accessible open space
page.description:
*Possible source maps*, generated through flow analysis, show which specific sources actually generate carriers that reach users, independent of the existence of sinks but taking into account use values and the carrier flow paths. Even in the absence of sinks, not all of a source quantity can actually reach users, because of the route that an ecosystem service carrier moves across the landscape.
For provisioning services, this corresponds to the source of benefits that has the potential of being actually useful. For preventive services, this corresponds to the sources that could actually cause damage to people. The location and strength of sinks determines how much of the source actually reaches the users.
This map shows open space providing value when accounting for proximity and the location of homeowners but not highways that limit local access.
page.see-also: Aesthetic viewshed and proximity model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Open space proximate homeowners
page.title: Open space proximate homeowners
page.description:
*Possible use maps* show the locations of users that can receive a benefit due to flow connections with a source of an ecosystem service carrier, but may or may not actually receive the carrier due to the action of sinks.
For provisioning services, potential use identifies areas where it is physically possible for a benefit to be received. For preventive services, potential use identifies areas that may be damaged by a detrimental carrier if sinks do not prevent such damage.
This map shows homeowners benefiting from proximity after accounting for sources of open space and their flow paths, but before accounting for highways that limit local access.
page.see-also: Aesthetic viewshed and proximity model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Accessible proximity
page.title: Accessible proximity flow
page.description:
*Actual flow maps* show the flow paths that deliver actual services to beneficiaries. These are selected from the total flow density to only show these flow paths that are not depleted by sinks and actually reach users.
For provisioning services, these flow paths deliver valuable benefits to the users and the density is proportional to the value accrued. For preventive services, the flow paths show how much of the carrier reaches users, delivering actual damage.
This map shows the actual flow of proximity from natural areas toward homeowners, when accounting for sinks and flow paths.
page.see-also: Aesthetic viewshed and proximity model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Enjoyed open space
page.title: Enjoyed open space
page.description:
*Actual source maps* show sources that actually provide a service after accounting for sinks and flow dynamics.
For provisioning services, this is the amount and location of a benefit that actually provides benefits to the users. For preventive services, it shows where the actual damage came from. Source regions that provided a damaging carrier that was neutralized by sinks are not shown.
This map shows open space providing proximity when accounting for flow paths, sinks, and the location of beneficiaries.
page.see-also: Aesthetic viewshed and proximity model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Blocking proximity sink
page.title: Blocking proximity sink
page.description:
*Actual sink maps* shows the sinks that actually contribute to depleting a service carrier given its flow patterns.
For provisioning services, such sinks reduce benefits to users compared to their possible value. For preventive services, such sinks provide the actual service because they prevent a damaging carrier from reaching users.
This map shows highways that actually separate residences from nearby open space.
page.see-also: Aesthetic viewshed and proximity model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Homeowners with proximate open space
page.title: Homeowners with proximate open space
page.description:
*Actual use maps* show the level of use of a beneficial carrier for a provisioning service or damage caused by a detrimental carrier for a preventive service, for users.
This map shows homeowners benefiting from proximity after accounting for sources of open space, sinks, and flow paths.
page.see-also: Aesthetic viewshed and proximity model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Homeowners without proximate open space
page.title: Homeowners without proximate open space
page.description:
*Inaccessible use maps* shows potential users that cannot receive a service due to a lack of flow routes linking source and user locations.
For provisioning services, this corresponds to value produced by the environment that cannot be reached by users. For preventive services, it corresponds to damage that could have been inflicted on users but is not due to a lack of flow connections to users.
This map shows homeowners lacking any proximity to open space due to their location (typically in urban areas).
page.see-also: Aesthetic viewshed and proximity model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Blocked proximity
page.title: Blocked proximity
page.description:
*Blocked flow maps* show flow paths that could have delivered an ecosystem service to humans based on the flow routes and source and user locations, but did not because of the action of sinks. These are selected from among all actual flows.
For provisioning services, these flow paths show the loss of possible beneficial service flow to users, and their density is proportional to the value lost. For preventive services, the flow paths show the amount of the total flow that was prevented by natural features from causing damage.
This map shows flows of open space proximity toward homeowners that are blocked by highways.
page.see-also: Aesthetic viewshed and proximity model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Blocked open space
page.title: Blocked open space
page.description:
*Blocked source maps* show sources that had the possibility of reaching users given the location of users and flow dynamics, but were blocked from doing so because of the action of sinks.
For provisioning services, this corresponds to value produced by the environment but lost before it could reach the users. For preventive services, it corresponds to damage that could have been inflicted on users but was blocked by natural features.
This map shows open space that is blocked by the action of sinks (highways).
page.see-also: Aesthetic viewshed and proximity model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Homeowners with blocked proximity
page.title: Homeowners with blocked proximity
page.description:
*Blocked use maps* show users that would have received a service carrier based on source and flow dynamics, but did not because of the action of sinks.
For provisioning services, the map shows possible value that were prevented by sinks from reaching users; for preventive services, it shows actual value accrued by users from sinks that blocked damaging flows. For preventive services, therefore, this map is the ultimate quantification of value given the locations and quantity of users and sink features.
This map shows homeowners who would receive benefits from open space proximity but have their access blocked by highways.
page.see-also: Aesthetic viewshed and proximity model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.
